listitems.content: I know how to explain what some of the tools do in a frontend build setup, but I don't know where to start when making my own boilerplate

sections.title: A Hope
sections.subTitle: As a developer I'd like to...

listitems.content: ...know how to setup a project's dependencies as a first step of a frontend boilerplate

sections.title: A Practice
sections.subTitle: Here, we will leverage npm to initialize a project and install a handful of webpack dependencies. This will not be all dependencies, just enough needed to get the npm consuming, bundling, and storing some code output.

listitems.title: Create A Repo
listitems.content: Maybe call it 'frontend-boilerplate'. This will be the folder that will hold the boilerplate.

listitems.title: Initialize as an NPM Repo
contentlist: Open a terminal, cd in to the newly created repo.
From the terminal, run the command `npm init -y`

This 'sets up' the repo to leverage npm for the following steps. Now, there will be a package.json file, which acts as the 'config' for npm to know what to do with dependencies, and what files to work with.

listitems.title: Install some dependencies
contentlist: from the cli, run `npm install --save-dev webpack webpack-dev-server webpack-cli html-webpack-plugin`
This 'sets up' the repo to leverage npm for the next steps.
Here, webpack dependencies are installed, ready to 'consume' some javascript, reaady to serve in a dev server, and even ready to 'build' into code that is 'ready for production'.
This will update the `devDependencies` section of the package.json, and list the above webpack dependencies that were just installed.
